phrases.text: I’m afraid there’s an issue with…
phrases.usage: Use this to soften the delivery of bad news or a complaint by employing hedging, which makes the tone more polite and less accusatory.
phrases.example: I’m afraid there’s an issue with the logic board, as the system consistently fails to boot after the recent firmware update.

phrases.text: Could we look at a couple of options?
phrases.usage: This phrase is used to signal a desire for a collaborative negotiation, suggesting that the initial solution offered might not be the only way forward.
phrases.example: Since the cost of the original manufacturer's parts is quite high, could we look at a couple of options involving certified third-party components?

phrases.text: What would you be able to do on your side?
phrases.usage: A subtle way to invite the other party to offer a concession or a discount without making a direct or aggressive demand for one.
phrases.example: Given that I have been a loyal customer for five years, what would you be able to do on your side to reduce the total labor costs for this repair?

phrases.text: To be clear, I’m asking for…
phrases.usage: Use this for assertive clarification to ensure there is no ambiguity regarding your expectations or the specific outcome you require.
phrases.example: To be clear, I’m asking for a comprehensive diagnostic report and a written guarantee before any hardware modifications are made.

phrases.text: That doesn’t quite solve the problem because…
phrases.usage: A nuanced way to reject a proposed solution by focusing on the logic of the situation rather than being confrontational.
phrases.example: That doesn’t quite solve the problem because the display flickering persists even when I use a different power adapter, suggesting an internal fault.

phrases.text: Is there any flexibility on the timeline?
phrases.usage: A professional way to negotiate a deadline or turnaround time, implying that the current schedule is inconvenient without being demanding.
phrases.example: Because I have a major presentation on Monday, is there any flexibility on the timeline to expedite the screen replacement process?

phrases.text: Could you confirm what happens next?
phrases.usage: Use this to establish a clear procedural plan and ensure accountability by asking for a step-by-step breakdown of the post-negotiation process.
phrases.example: Now that we have agreed on the price, could you confirm what happens next regarding the tracking of my device through the repair cycle?

phrases.text: I’d appreciate it if we could…
phrases.usage: A formal conditional structure used to propose a preferred action while maintaining a respectful and advanced tone.
phrases.example: I’d appreciate it if we could prioritize the data recovery phase before you attempt to format the internal drive.

phrases.text: If that’s not possible, the next best thing is…
phrases.usage: A classic negotiation tactic used to present a secondary alternative or 'fallback position' if your primary request cannot be met.
phrases.example: If that’s not possible due to your current inventory levels, the next best thing is a temporary loaner device so I can continue my work.

phrases.usage: A polite closing phrase used to acknowledge the resolution of a complex situation and leave the interaction on a positive note.
phrases.example: I really value the transparency you've shown regarding the hidden fees; thanks for sorting this out so professionally.

keyVocabulary.definition: Occurring at irregular intervals; not continuous or steady, often used to describe hardware glitches.
Something that is granted or given up in a negotiation to reach an agreement.
The total amount of time it takes to complete a specific task or repair from start to finish.
A formal investigation or test performed to identify the root cause of a technical failure.
To make a process happen more quickly than the standard speed.
